prompt: Facts: Incident occurred on 03.07.1992.; Prosecutrix (PW1) alleged she was raped by Inder Singh (Respondent No. 2) and two others (originally accused, acquitted by Trial Court).; Prosecutrix informed her parents about the incident on the morning of 04.07.1992.; First Information Report (FIR) was lodged on 04.07.1992 at 10:45 AM at Police Station Sadar Bhiwani.; Medical examination of the prosecutrix was conducted on 04.07.1992.; Medical report indicated no external or internal injuries on the prosecutrix.; Vaginal swabs were taken, but the chemical examiner's report regarding semen was negative.; The Trial Court acquitted all three accused persons, disbelieving the prosecutrix's testimony citing delay in FIR and lack of corroborative medical evidence.; The State of Haryana filed an appeal in the High Court against the acquittal.; The High Court upheld the acquittal of the two other accused but reversed the acquittal of Inder Singh (Respondent No. 2), convicting him under Section 376 IPC and sentencing him to 7 years Rigorous Imprisonment.; Inder Singh appealed to the Supreme Court against his conviction.; The State of Haryana also filed an appeal (Cr. Appeal No. 1035 of 1997) against the High Court's judgment upholding the acquittal of the other two accused.; The Supreme Court heard both appeals together. | IPC: Section 376 (Punishment for Rape), Section 375 (Rape - Definition, as applicable in 1992), Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention - initially relevant, less so after acquittal of co-accused)
completion: {"prosecution": [{"argument": "The testimony of the prosecutrix (PW1) is credible, reliable, and sufficient for conviction, even without corroboration.", "precedents": ["State of Punjab v. Gurmit Singh (1996) 2 SCC 384", "State of Himachal Pradesh v. Shree Kant Shekari (2004) 8 SCC 153", "State of U.P. v. Pappu @ Yunus (2005) 3 SCC 594"]}, {"argument": "The delay in lodging the FIR (from evening of 03.07.1992 to morning of 04.07.1992) is minor and reasonably explained by the trauma and social circumstances of a rape victim.", "precedents": ["Appabhai v. State of Gujarat (AIR 1988 SC 696)", "Harbans Lal v. State of Himachal Pradesh (1989) 4 SCC 459", "State of Punjab v. Gurmit Singh (1996) 2 SCC 384"]}, {"argument": "Absence of injuries on the prosecutrix and negative semen report do not disprove rape, as injuries are not always present and semen may not always be detected.", "precedents": ["State of U.P. v. Babul Nath (1994) 6 SCC 29", "State of Karnataka v. Sureshbabu Puk Raj Porral (1994) 2 SCC 466", "Madan Gopal Kakkad v. Naval Dubey (1992) 3 SCC 204"]}], "defense": [{"argument": "The Trial Court rightly acquitted based on lack of corroboration and delay; High Court erred in reversing acquittal without finding the Trial Court's view perverse.", "precedents": ["Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka (2007) 4 SCC 415", "Ramesh Babulal Doshi v. State of Gujarat (1996) 9 SCC 225", "Basappa v. State of Karnataka (2014) 5 SCC 154"]}, {"argument": "The delay in lodging the FIR is significant and unexplained, raising doubts about the veracity of the complaint.", "precedents": ["Thulia Kali v. State of Tamil Nadu (1972) 3 SCC 393", "State of Punjab v. Gurdeep Singh (1999) 9 SCC 87", "Rajesh Patel vs State of Jharkhand (2013) 3 SCC 791"]}, {"argument": "Complete absence of medical evidence (no injuries, negative semen report) corroborating the prosecutrix's allegation of forceful intercourse.", "precedents": ["Raju v. State of Madhya Pradesh (2008) 15 SCC 133", "Krishan Kumar Malik v. State of Haryana (2011) 7 SCC 130", "Narender Kumar vs State (NCT of Delhi) (2012) 7 SCC 171"]}, {"argument": "The prosecution relies solely on the testimony of the prosecutrix, which has been deemed unreliable by the Trial Court, and lacks independent corroboration.", "precedents": ["Vadivelu Thevar v. State of Madras (AIR 1957 SC 614)", "Suraj Mal vs State (Delhi Administration) (1979) 4 SCC 725", "Kaini Rajan v. State of Kerala (2013) 9 SCC 113"]}]}
